awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Multiple Scale Biomechanics of Tissue Damage in the White Matter of the Human Central Nervous System
awd_abstract_narration:
The debilitating long-term consequences of traumatic brain injury (TBI) caused by head impacts in sports or blast effects in war are now generally recognized as dangerous.  Even milder head impacts require patient monitoring, though for how long is not completely known.  To care for people with less obvious injuries and to measure whether a patient has healed, new approaches to brain imaging are needed.  This research is targeted at improving the prediction and monitoring of brain injuries.  A loss of white matter is one of the changes in brain tissue after injury. How the head impact is distributed as stress in the brain is not known, nor do we know the tolerance of brain cells to stress. This research project will use fast confocal microscopy and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) techniques to develop and validate a multiscale mechanical model for brain white matter that can predict cell injury.  This validated model will be used to estimate axonal injury in the brain using impact models of the whole brain.  The research will be used in the education of undergraduate and graduate students.  The PI instituted the GirlsConnect club in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering to increase the participation and retention of women in this field.

This project will focus on identifying the injury thresholds for individual axons within white matter when the tissue is exposed to dynamic, mechanical stretch. This interdisciplinary research builds on the innovative experimental approaches to understand axon kinematics and novel multi-scale computational models of the collaborative team to introduce: (i) Analysis of axon-level displacements and sub-failure axonal damage following clinically-relevant, dynamic loading of white matter; (ii) Computational incorporation of the composite mechanics of axon and glial matrix interaction, including damage, into the global (macro) response of the white matter following tissue-scale loading; (iii) Quantitative prediction of stress concentrations at the axon-level from the computational models; and (iv) Integration of clinical imaging (MRI and Magnetic Resonance Elastography) and subsequent histopathology and correlation of mechanical properties to axonal damage. The multi-scale model will enable the prediction of changes in bulk mechanical properties from damage to the axonal microstructure and from myelin degeneration. It is anticipated that this model can be easily integrated into advanced imaging modalities to predict and monitor brain injury and disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
The broad, long-term objective of this research is to quantitatively understand the multi-scale mechanics associated with traumatic injury to central nervous system (CNS) white matter. This includes evaluating how stress and strain are transferred to individual components of neural tissue; the tolerance before physical and/or functional damage occurs; and how this damage can exacerbate further physical and/or functional damage in the tissue. This information is vital for identifying the circumstances that cause both mild-traumatic brain injury (mTBI) and TBI. This study aims to quantitatively predict the viscoelastic material properties and consequently damage in brain white matter (BWM). A finite element (FE) based fractional viscoelastic model characterizing the time dependent behavior of the axons in BWM has been developed. Unit cells  of hexagonally packed axons in glia are modeled and subjected to a quasi-static displacement boundary condition. Homogenized orthotropic fractional material properties of the composite are extracted by solving the inverse problem. The results from these simulations predict that the homogenized structure becomes stiffer and more viscous with higher volume fractions. The variation, however, is not linear. This observation is especially important when viewed in relation to current MRI-based evidence relating changes in volume fraction during neurodegenerative processes such as aging which predicts a linear variation.

Considering the fact these simulations are compute-intensive, a computationally efficient scheme has been developed by formulating an efficient method to store and retrieve the response history of the material, deploying different compiler optimization methods for the material subroutines, improving the subroutines’ memory handling, and performing loop-level optimization with OpenMP for Fortran subroutines and domain-level parallelization in Abaqus. With these methods, the simulation time for the largest model was reduced from 52 hours to 46 hours when run on a single core with 16 threads.

We are developing a damage model of BWM by formulating a damage evolution function that can capture the progressive failure of the axons from tissue-based experiments. Axonal nerve damage and myelin degradation in BMW are among the factors responsible for the deterioration in brain tissue's mechanical and functional performance during trauma-like events. In this study, damage is hypothesized as a progressive softening of the material model due to the deterioration of myelin under the application of finite strains. The softening is characterized by introducing a damage function that takes continuous values between 0 and 1.

The microstructure is characterized by a hyperelastic strain energy (SE) density function. Hexagonally packed unit cells (UCs) are developed and a vectorized user material subroutine in Fortran that characterizes the damaged strain energy density function in the axonal fibers (AF) as a function of the amount of myelin is formulated. The parameters of the damage function are computed via an optimization scheme that compares the softening stress response with experimental data. We intend to implement lessons learned from Aim-1 in speeding up our simulations using job arrays in the future.

This research study developed a fundamental understanding of brain injury and its relevance in detecting mTBI which is currently undetectable by standard diagnostic tools such as MRI and DTI. The study created fundamental knowledge to help identify material response and trauma in BWM while accounting for tissue architecture and damage invariants. The direct correlation to physically observed events during trauma, such as myelin degradation in the axonal microstructure, reinforces the impact of this work. Additionally, the development of scientific computing software for modeling and analyzing trauma in brain will help the broader brain modeling community.

Why is this important for the general population? One of the major issues that impede the development of therapies is the fact that it is challenging to diagnose TBI. Our tools can enable traumatic axonal injury (TAI) diagnosis in different parts of the brain. As the TBI cases are underdiagnosed due to our inability to identify, especially mTBI (mild-TBI), a large population of people who suffer from disabilities, including personality changes, depression and anxiety, and difficulty completing tasks, may go undiagnosed. Additional urgency for diagnostic tools is based on the fact that patients have a life expectancy of less than ten years after a TBI. The development of diagnostic and prognostic tools to identify these patients will allow for proper treatment and the development of therapies that will allow them to have a better quality of life and to function better in society. Furthermore, early diagnosis and therapeutic intervention could increase life expectancy after TBI. Our model predicts changes in bulk mechanical properties from damage to the axonal microstructure and myelin degeneration, which could be integrated into advanced imaging modalities to provide a unique mechanical signature or injury and disease.


Last Modified: 02/04/2024
Modified by: Assimina A Pelegri

    Pasupathy, P. and Pelegri, A.A.
    Copyrighted
    Assimina A Pelegri
    Volume Fraction Effect on Neuronal Axons
  • a) Hex packed UCs, homogenized AF w/myelin & axon, periodic UC FEM. b) Optimization: damage parameter healthy (hea) & demyelinated (dem) tissue, damage function variation w/ SE density w/varying myelination. c) Brain tissue damage for hea & dem tissue, Softened stress vs VF keeping myelin constant.
    Pasupathy, P. and Pelegri, A.A.
    Copyrighted
    Assimina A Pelegri
    Optimization Scheme of Homogenized Brain Tissue
